p: Vitamin D exerts antimicrobial and anti-oxidant effects and supports the immune system against respiratory infection [ 58]. According to a meta-analysis vitamin D supplementation reduces the risk of acute respiratory infections [ 59], has been inversely related to hepatitis viral load [ 60] and improves antibacterial immunity in HIV-1 patients [ 61]. An inverse association between mean levels of vitamin D and the number of COVID-19 cases/1 M was recently reported in a cross-sectional European study [ 62] whereas a UK study did not find an association between the vitaminâ€™s status and COVID-19 risk [ 63]. Moreover, low levels of vitamin D were found in COVID-19 positive patients [ 64] or hospitalized patients with COVID-19 [ 65] and have been connected to the severity of the disease. The hypothesis that vitamin D may explain susceptibility to COVID-19 infection in dark colored skin individuals does not seem to be valid [ 63]. It is noteworthy that several clinical trials are on the way regarding the role of vitamin D in the prevention and treatment of COVID-19, reviewed elsewhere [ 48].
